name: L'Hôpital's Rule
latex: \lim_{x \to a} \frac{f(x)}{g(x)} = \lim_{x \to a} \frac{f'(x)}{g'(x)} \text{ if } \lim f = \lim g = 0 \text{ or } \pm\infty
explanation: L'Hôpital's rule evaluates limits of indeterminate forms (0/0 or ∞/∞) by taking derivatives of the numerator and denominator. If the limit of f/g is indeterminate, and the limit of f'/g' exists, then they are equal. This powerful technique simplifies many limit calculations that would otherwise be difficult.
proof: If lim f(x)/g(x) gives 0/0 or ∞/∞, and f'(x)/g'(x) exists, then lim f(x)/g(x) = lim f'(x)/g'(x). Proof uses Mean Value Theorem: f(x)/g(x) = [f(x) - f(a)]/[g(x) - g(a)] = f'(c)/g'(c) for some c between a and x. As x → a, c → a, so limit equals f'(a)/g'(a) if derivatives exist.
